analyzed: jātaka  ti sa nipāta  ki chanda vagga
translated: Jātaka🔽Thirty-Third Chapter🔽The Chapter about Desires
The Story of the Six-Tusked Elephant
“Why are you so sad, Uccangi,
pale, of excellent complexion,
withering, large-eyed one,
like a garland that has been trampled?”

analyzed: dohaḷaḥ me mahā rāja  supin antena upajjhagā
translated: “A dream appeared to me, great king,
that I cannot easily find,🔽such as my dream was,
such is my desire.”
“Whatever human desires there are,
here in this world that delights,
all of them are at my disposal,
I give you your desire.”
“Let the hunters come together,
whatever there are in your realm;
I will show them,
such as my desire was.”

analyzed: ime te luddakāḥ devi  katahatthā visāradā
translated: “These are the hunters, queen,🔽skilled in the use of their hands, confident,
skilled in the forest and skilled in the animal,
their lives are in my hands.”
“Listen, sons of the hunters,
all of you who have come here;

analyzed: chat bisānam gajam seta  addasam supine aha
translated: I saw in a dream a white elephant with six tusks,
I need his tusks,

original: alābhe natthi jīvitaṁ”.🔽“Na no pitūnaṁ na pitāmahānaṁ,
analyzed: alābhe natthi jīvita  na naḥ pitūnam na pitāmahāna
translated: without them there is no life for me.”🔽“We have never seen or heard of a six-tusked elephant,
neither our fathers nor our grandfathers,
“Yamadaṇḍa saw in a dream a prince,
Tell us what kind of elephant it was.”
“The four cardinal directions and the four intermediate directions,
Above and below, these are the ten directions;
In which direction does the king of elephants stand,
Yamadaṇḍa saw in a dream the one with six tusks?”
“Straight from here in the northern direction,
Passing beyond the seven mountains,
There is a great mountain named Suvaṇṇapāda,
Full of flowers, frequented by kinnaras.
Having climbed the rock, the abode of the kinnaras,
Look at the foot of the mountain;
Then you will see a banyan king, the color of a cloud,
Eight thousand feet tall.
There stands the six-tusked elephant,
All white, unbearable to others;
Eight thousand elephants protect him,
With tusks like spears, swift as the wind.
They stand in a heap, watching,
They tremble even at the wind blowing;
But having seen a human being there,

analyzed: bhasmam kareyyum na assa rajaḥ api tassa
translated: They would reduce him to ashes, not even his dust would remain.”

analyzed: bahū hime rājakulamhi santi  piḷandhanā jātarūpassa devī
translated: “There are many in the king’s household,🔽the queen is adorned with gold,
with pearls, gems, and cat’s eyes.🔽What will you do with a tusk for an ornament?

analyzed: kim danta piḍandhanena  mā āretu kāmā kuñjaram chabbisāṇa
translated: Do you want to kill the six-tusked one?
Or will you kill the hunter’s son?”
“I am jealous and unhappy, hunter,
and I am thirsty looking up and remembering.
Do this for me, hunter,

original: Dassāmi te gāmavarāni pañca”.🔽“Katthacchatī kattha mupeti ṭhānaṁ,
analyzed: dassāmi te gām avarāni pañca  katthacchatī kattha mupeti
translated: and I will give you five excellent villages.”🔽“Where does he go? Where is his place?
Where is his path when he goes to bathe?
How does the king of elephants bathe?
How can we know the elephant’s whereabouts?”
“Right there is a pond not far away,
beautiful, with a good ford and a large area.
It is in full bloom, frequented by swarms of bees.

analyzed: ettha hi saḥ nhāyati nāga rājā
translated: That is where the king of elephants bathes.
Having bathed his head, wearing a garland of lotuses,
all white, with the color of a lotus on his cheeks,
he goes, fragrant, to his rendezvous,
with the queen, the best of all, in front of him.”
There he took up his position,

original: Ādāya tūṇiñca dhanuñca luddo;🔽Vituriyati sattagirī brahante,🔽Suvaṇṇapassaṁ nāma giriṁ uḷāraṁ.
analyzed: ādāya tūṇiñca dhanuñca luddaḥ  vituriyati satta girī brahante  suvaṇṇapassam nāma girim uḷāra
translated: and the hunter, taking his bow and arrows,🔽went to the top of the mountain called Suvaṇṇapassaya,
which was very high and resounded with the cries of birds.🔽He climbed up the mountain and went to the palace of the Kinnaras,
and looked down at the foot of the mountain.
There he saw a Nigrodha king,
eight thousand fathoms high, with a colour like a cloud.
There he saw a six-tusked elephant,
all white, invincible to others,
guarded by eight thousand elephants,
with tusks like spears, swift as the wind.
Not far from there he saw a lotus pond,
delightful, with a good bathing place and a large area,
covered with flowers, frequented by swarms of bees,

analyzed: yattha hi saḥ nhāyati nāga rājā
translated: where the elephant king bathed.
Having seen the elephant’s movements and his resting place,
the path he took when going to bathe,
the hunter, of ignoble appearance,

analyzed: citta vasā anugāya  khaṇitvāna kāsum phalakehi
translated: sent by Cittavasa, came to the place.🔽Having dug a pit, he covered it with planks,
and the hunter, for his own destruction, took his bow and arrows,
The elephant was seen pierced by the arrow,
and the one who had done the wicked deed was happy.
The elephant, pierced, let out a terrible cry,
and all the elephants ran to the terrible-looking low ground;

analyzed: tiṇam ca kaṭṭham ca raṇam karontā
translated: making grass and sticks their weapons,
they ran in the eight directions all around.
Thinking “I will kill him,”🔽he saw the saffron robe, the banner of the seers;
when he was touched by suffering, the perception arose in him,
“The banner of the Worthy One, who is blameless in all ways.”

analyzed: a nikkasāvaḥ kāsāva  yaḥ vattham paridahissati
translated: “One who has not given up the corruptions,🔽who puts on the robe out of desire,
has departed from self-control and truth,
he does not deserve the saffron robe.
But one who has given up the corruptions,
who is well-composed in the precepts,
who has attained self-control and truth,
he deserves the saffron robe.”
The elephant, pierced by the arrow,
with an untroubled mind spoke to the hunter:
“For what purpose, for what reason,

original: Mamaṁ vadhī kassa vāyaṁ payogo”.🔽“Kāsissa rañño mahesī bhadante,
analyzed: mamam vadhī kassa vā ayam payogaḥ  kāsissa raññaḥ mahesī bhadante
translated: do you kill me? For whose use is this?”🔽“The queen of King Kāsī, reverend Sir,
she, Subhaddā, is worshipped in the royal family;

original: Taṁ addasā sā ca mamaṁ asaṁsi,
translated: She saw me and was frightened,

analyzed: dantehi attha iti ca mama avoca
translated: And said to me: ‘My tusks are gone!’”

analyzed: bahū hi me danta yugā uḷārā
translated: “I have many pairs of tusks, great tusks,
Which were my father’s and my grandfather’s.
The angry princess knows this,
The foolish one has killed me for my tusks.
Rise up, hunter, take your axe,
And cut off these tusks before I die;
You must tell that angry princess,
‘The elephant is dead, here are his tusks!’”
The hunter rose up, took his axe,
And cut off the tusks of the chief of the herd;
They were beautiful, of good form, and unbroken,
And he quickly left the place.
Terrified by the death of the elephant,

original: Ye te nāgā aṭṭha disā vidhāvuṁ;
translated: The elephants fled in the eight directions;

analyzed: a disvāna posam gaja pacca mitta
translated: Not seeing the elephant’s enemy,

analyzed: pacca āgamum yena saḥ nāga rājā
translated: They returned to where the king of elephants was.
There the elephants wailed and wept,

original: Sīse sake paṁsukaṁ okiritvā;🔽Agamaṁsu te sabbe sakaṁ niketaṁ,
analyzed: sīse sake pasukam okiritvā  agamasu te sabbe sakam niketa
translated: And threw dust on their own heads;🔽They all went back to their own abode,
With the great lord, the best of all, at the head.
Taking the tusks of the chief of the herd,
beautiful, excellent, and unblemished,
all over inlaid with gold,
that hunter went to the city of Kāsi.
He presented the tusks to the king’s daughter,
“The tusks of the slain elephant.”
Seeing the tusks of the chief of the herd,
of her husband, dear to her, in a former existence,
her heart burst right there,
and the foolish one died right there.
Having attained great awakening, the one of great power,
in the midst of the assembly, he smiled.
The monks, their minds well-liberated, asked,
“The Buddhas do not smile without a reason.
What did you see, young girl,
that you went forth in the ochre robe?

analyzed: sā kho tadā rāja kaññā ahosi
translated: At that time, she was the king’s daughter,
and I was the king of elephants.
Taking the tusks of the chief of the herd,
beautiful, excellent, and unblemished,
the hunter who went to the city of Kāsi,
at that time, he was Devadatta.”
The one without a core, long dwelt in saṃsāra,
“This is the ancient way of life, high and low,
Free from anger, free from sorrow, free from defilements,

original: Sayaṁ abhiññāya abhāsi buddho.🔽“Ahaṁ vo tena kālena,
analyzed: sayam abhiññāya abhāsi buddhaḥ  aham vaḥ tena kālena
translated: The Buddha, having known it by his own super-knowledge, has spoken.🔽“At that time, monks,
I was the one there;
I was the king of the nāgas then,
remember this as the Birth Story.”
The Birth Story of Chaddanta, the fourth.
